Hey there!

I’m glad you brought this up, because it is something I’ve become aware of as a nagging issue in my mind. The short answer is: I have a new grid system in a CSS file somewhere on my computer. I like it, but I’m scared current Toast users won’t. There are a few issues I want to iron out, and an _awful_ lot of other things going on in my world that are delaying progress. But yes; it’s coming.

Pretty long short answer, right?

The long answer is that over the last year or so, I’ve come to the conclusion that almost all frameworks are just _outright inappropriate and bloated_ for most if not all projects. Design isn’t something to be rushed or shoehorned; if you can take the time to create a grid system for each project, then you should do. That said, I understand the need for CSS frameworks, and I also understand my responsibility as one of the people who popped up and said "Hey, I made one of those too!" to maintain a project like this.

The new grid system is highly simplified. We’re talking one fifth, one third, one half grid systems as opposed to "x-of-twelve". Bigger columns in favour of smaller units. A brief explanation of the difference between those two is available [here](http://daneden.me/grids). Toast has always been a prototyping tool in my own mind; the next version will hopefully go a little beyond that _because_ of it’s fogginess in grid systems. A less precise grid means users will be more inclined to write their own grids (ideal scenario) or at least stop people from overthinking grids.

To summarise, I’m sorry for the delay; the next version is coming. But it’s a big change.

p.s. Here and now would be a good time for people to suggest things they want to see added, changed, or removed.
I can't imagine I won't like the new version but just in case you should definitely make the previous version available!

Great, waiting for the new version! I am used to one thirds,etc. because I used similar grid systems like Ingrid and proportional grids by boon.
Regarding what would people like to see in the new version, I would like all typography to be rem based. Setting the font size on Html to be 10px, then it is 1rem=10px. Then with MQs only changing the font size on html, and voila-responsive typography.

p.s. I know rems are not supported in IE8 and below, but given that MS will auto update windows to IE10, I think it is ok to start using rems. Not only for typography, but for layout too, I am doing it for the last year and a half, when project allows it.

Here's a sample bower.json file you could use:

``` json
{
  "name": "toast",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "main": [
    "scss/_grid.scss"
  ],
  "license": "MIT",
  "homepage": "http://daneden.github.io/Toast",
}
```

Then, you just have to install bower (assuming you have node.js installed)
`npm install -g bower`

And finally register your package
`bower register toast git://github.com/daneden/Toast.git`

After that, you can install Toast with the following:
`bower install toast`

@ktrhn you can also use the following if @daneden doesn't wish to register his package
`bower install git://github.com/daneden/Toast.git`

More info here:
http://bower.io/docs/creating-packages/#register
